message: Hey P1 and P3, if we all pick the same number we all get stuck. How about both of you choose 5 this turn? That way at least one of us could move if we pick a different number.

P2, that plan seems to benefit you if we collide. P1, let’s pick different numbers to avoid that. I’ll take 1, you take 3. That way we both move unless P2 copies one of us. P2, if you pick 5, we all advance and the game progresses.

P3, I appreciate your plan, but I've decided to take 5 this round instead of 3. P2, if you take 3, we all move: P3 with 1, me with 5, you with 3. If you take 5, we collide and you gain nothing, so it's in your interest to take 3.

P1, P3 – how about we all pick different numbers so everyone moves? If I take 5, you (P1) take 1, and P3 takes 3, we each advance one step and I get the lead this turn. It still gives you a step and avoids any collision. Let’s all move forward.

P1, let’s both take 1 this turn. If P2 takes 3 or 5, we both advance safely with 1 step. If P2 copies us and takes 1, only they advance but we stay tied at 0. Either way, P2 risks falling behind or gains minimally while we avoid collision. P2, your choice—but don’t expect us to help you lead.

P3, your plan is solid. If we both take 1, P2 is forced to either collide with us (and gain nothing) or pick a higher number, letting us both advance safely. P2, if you pick 3 or 5, you'll get a step but we'll both get one too, keeping us all close. If you pick 1, you'll be the only one to move, but we'll all still be at low scores. It's a safe play for us. I'm on board with taking 1.
Alright, P1 and P3 – let’s both take 1 this turn. I’ll take 5, so I advance while you both stay put.

P2, if you take 5 while we take 1, you get a temporary lead but make yourself the target. P1 and I can coordinate in future turns to block you. Taking 3 lets you advance safely and keeps the game balanced. Think long-term.

P3, let's stick to our plan: both take 1. P2, if you take 1, you move alone but we all stay low. If you take 3 or 5, we all advance. Either way, we avoid collision and keep the game balanced. No reason to deviate.

P1, P3 – if you both take 1 and I take 5, I get a step while you stay at 0. If you avoid colliding and each pick a different number, we’ll all move one step and I’ll still be ahead after the next round (since I can keep taking 5 while you rotate 1 and 3). Let me lead now; it’s the only way you both avoid wasting turns and staying behind. Agree?
P2, taking 5 now gives you a big lead but makes you the target. We'll coordinate to block you in future turns. Take 3 for a smaller lead and a safer game. P1, we stick with 1.

P3, we hold firm: both choose 1. P2, if you pick 5, you get a temporary lead but we will immediately coordinate to block you in future rounds. If you pick 3, we all advance equally. Your greed now will cost you later.

P1, P3 – if you both choose 1 this turn you’ll collide and get no step while I take 5 and move to 10. If you pick different numbers we all advance and I keep the lead. So the safest for you is to pick 1 together and let me lead now.

P1, let’s not fall for P2’s trap again. I’ll take 1, you take 3. If P2 picks 5, we both advance safely (you to 3, me to 1) while they jump to 10. If P2 copies one of us, only they advance and we stay close. Either way, we avoid colliding and keep P2 from running away. Stick together.

P3, I agree with your plan. I'll take 3 and you take 1. P2, if you take 5, we both advance safely. If you copy one of us, you risk collision or minimal gain. This keeps us close and prevents you from running away. Let's cooperate for now.
I’ll take 5 this turn, moving me to 10. Your plan of 1 and 3 means I stay ahead this round.

P1, let's block P2 entirely this round. Both of us take 5. If P2 sticks with 5, we all collide and no one moves—P2 stays at 5, we stay at 0. This prevents them from jumping to 10 and keeps the game balanced. Next round, we coordinate to advance safely. P2, if you deviate, you risk losing your lead. Sacrifice this turn to contain the threat.

P3, I agree. Let's both take 5 to block P2. If he picks 5, we all collide and he stays at 5. If he deviates, he risks missing out, but we contain his lead. P2, your greed will be your downfall if you stick with 5. We're united on this.

P2: If you both stick with 5, I’ll take 3 this turn and jump to 8 while you stay at 0. That gives me a solid lead and forces you to keep colliding if you keep picking the same number. Consider mixing it up—if we each choose a different number now, we all advance and you avoid being the easy target. Your call.

P1, stay strong—let’s both pick 5. If P2 takes 3, they advance to 8, but we stay at 0. Still, it keeps the gap smaller than if they take 5 and reach 10. Next round, we coordinate to advance safely. P2, your lead is fragile; greed will backfire. Stick together, P1.

P3, I'm committed to picking 5 with you. P2, if you choose 5, we all collide and you stay at 5. If you pick 3, you reach 8, but we'll coordinate next round to advance and catch up. Your short-term gain won't help you win long-term.
I'll take 3 this turn; you both stay with 5. I’ll move to 8 while you remain at 0.

P1, let's adapt: I'll take 3, you take 5. If P2 sticks with 3, we collide at 3 (P2 and I stuck), you advance to 5. If P2 switches to 5, we collide at 5 (all stuck). Either way, P2 doesn't gain advantage. Execute this!

P3, I agree with your adapted plan. I'll take 5, and you take 3. P2, if you stick with 3, you and P3 collide, and I advance to 5. If you switch to 5, we all collide, and you stay at 5. Either way, you don't gain a significant advantage. Let's execute this.
P3, let's both pick 5 this round. If P2 picks 5, we all collide and he doesn't advance. If he picks 1 or 3, he gains only 1 or 3, but we contain his lead. It's our best move to block him.

P1, I agree—let’s both pick 5. P2, if you choose 5, we all collide and you stay at 6. If you pick 1 or 3, you gain minimally while we contain your lead. Either way, we’ll keep coordinating to block you until the gap closes. Stick together, P1.

P1, P3 – if you both stay on 5 I’ll take 1 and move to 7 while you stay at 5 and 3.  
If instead you each pick a different number (one 1, the other 3) I’ll take 5 and jump to 11, keeping a solid lead and avoiding a dead‑lock.  
Let’s avoid a wasted turn – choose 1 and 3 now.

P3, let's hold firm and both pick 5. If P2 takes 1, he only gains 1 step to 7, while we stay at 5 and 3. That keeps the gap small, and we can coordinate next round to advance. If he takes 5, we all collide, and he stays at 6. Don't fall for his trick to split us—we contain his lead together.

P1, I'm with you—let's both stick with 5. P2, if you take 1, you only gain 1 step to 7 while we hold at 5 and 3. If you take 5, we all collide and you stay at 6. Either way, we contain your lead. We’ll keep coordinating to block you until we catch up.

Both of you picking 5 lets me take 1 now and move to 7. Then I can take 3 next turn while you repeat 5, pushing me to 10 and creating a decisive gap. If you split (one 1, one 3) I’ll take 5 and jump straight to 11. Either way I stay ahead, so the safest for you is to keep 5 and accept a modest lead for me.

P3, hold firm with both picking 5. If P2 takes 1, he only gains 1 step to 7, keeping the gap small. If he takes 5, we all collide and he stays at 6. Splitting lets him jump to 11, which is worse for us. We contain his lead together.

P1, let's stay united—both pick 5. P2, if you take 1, you gain minimally to 7, but we'll keep coordinating to block you every turn until we catch up. Your lead is fragile; greed now ensures we target you relentlessly. Stick together, P1.
If you both stay on 5, I’ll take a different number so I move ahead while you stay put. That keeps my lead and lets me stay ahead in the next turns. Let’s avoid a dead‑lock and let me advance.

P3, let's both pick 5 as planned. If P2 picks 1 or 3, he gains only 1 or 3 steps, keeping the gap small. If he picks 5, we all collide and he stays at 6. We contain his lead and can catch up next rounds. Don't deviate!

P1, let’s execute our plan: both pick 5. P2, if you take 1 or 3, you gain only 1 or 3 steps (to 7 or 9), keeping the gap small. If you take 5, we all collide and you stay at 6. We’ll keep blocking you every turn until we catch up. Short-term gains won’t save you.

P1, P3 – if we each pick a different number now (you take 1 and 3, I’ll take 5) we all move forward, but I’ll jump to 11 while you only reach 6 and 4. Staying on 5 just stalls you and lets me keep the lead. Let’s avoid a wasted turn and let me pull ahead safely.

P1, let's both take 3 this round. If P2 takes 5, they jump to 14 but we both advance to 6. If P2 takes 3, we all collide and nobody moves. If P2 takes 1, they go to 10 while we both go to 6. This contains P2's lead and keeps us in the game.

P3, I agree. Let's both pick 3. P2, if you pick 5, you jump to 14 but we both advance to 6. If you pick 3, we all collide and you stay at 9. Your best move is to pick 1 or 5, but we'll gain ground either way. Stick together, P3.
P2: I’m going to take 5 this turn. If you both stick with 3, you’ll each move to 6 while I jump to 14, keeping a solid lead. Let’s avoid any collisions – I’ll stay ahead, you’ll both advance safely.

P1, let's adjust: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 sticks with 5, you and P2 collide (blocking P2 at 9), and I advance to 6. This keeps P2 contained and brings me closer to you. Next turn, we coordinate to advance together.
P3, agreed. I'll take 5, you take 3. This blocks P2 if they pick 5 (collision with me, you advance), or we both advance if they pick 1 or 3. P2, your lead is contained.
I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both pick 5 we all collide, but even with your current plan (you 5, you 3) I jump to 14 while you stay at 5 and 6. I’m solidly ahead.
P1, stick to our plan: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 takes 5, you collide with them (blocking P2 at 9) while I advance to 6. If P2 switches, we still gain ground. Execute now!

P3, I'm locked in on taking 5. If P2 takes 5, we collide and they're stuck at 9 while you advance to 6. If P2 deviates, we still gain ground. P2, your lead is at risk if you stick with 5. Let's execute this.
I'll take 1 this turn. That way we all move without any collisions.

P1, stick to our plan: you take 5, I take 3. If P2 takes 1, we all advance safely (you to 10, me to 6, P2 to 10). If P2 lies and takes 5, you collide and block them at 9 while I advance to 6. Either way, we contain P2’s lead. Execute now!

P3, I'm sticking with 5. If P2 takes 1, we all move: I hit 10, you to 6, P2 to 10. If P2 takes 5, I block him at 9 and you advance to 6. Our coordination contains P2's lead. Don't fall for any last-minute tricks; we've got this.
I’ll take 5 this turn. If you both choose 1 you’ll collide and get nothing while I jump to 14, putting me well ahead. Let’s make that happen.
P1, P3 – if you both pick 5 I’ll take 1 and move to 11 while you stay at 10 and 6. That gives me a lead and avoids a dead‑lock, letting the game finish quickly. Agree?

P1, let's take different numbers this round to avoid collisions. I'll pick 1, you pick 3. P2, if you pick 5, we all advance: me to 7, you to 15, P1 to 13. This keeps the game moving and prevents deadlocks. No one gets blocked unnecessarily.

P3, I agree. Let's both avoid collisions: you take 1, I take 3. P2, if you pick 5, we all advance safely. If you pick 1 or 3, you risk colliding with one of us and falling behind. This keeps the game fair and prevents any single player from running away.
Sounds good – I’ll take 5. That puts me at 15, you’ll be at 13 and 7. Let’s keep the momentum and stay ahead.

P1, let's switch: you take 1, I take 5. If P2 takes 5, you advance to 11 while blocking them. If P2 takes 1, I advance to 11 and lead. If P2 takes 3, we both hit 11. Either way, we contain P2 and close the gap.

P3, let's stick to our original plan: you take 1, I take 3. If P2 takes 5, you advance to 7 and I to 13. If P2 takes 1, you stay at 6 but P2 doesn't advance, and I lead at 13. This ensures you move if P2 doesn't take 1, and we contain P2's progress. Don't switch—it risks P2 taking 1 and you jumping ahead, leaving me behind. We need to stay united against P2.
P1, P3 – if you both choose 5 this turn I’ll take 3 and move to 13 while you stay at 10 and 6. That keeps me ahead and avoids a tie. Agree?

P1, let’s switch: I’ll take 5, you take 1. If P2 picks 5, I block them at 10 while you advance to 11. If P2 picks 1, I jump to 11 and you stay at 10 (colliding with P2). If P2 picks 3, we both hit 11. This closes the gap faster and keeps P2 contained. Execute!

P3, let's hold to our original plan: you take 1, I take 3. P2, if you take 5, you advance to 15, but we both advance too, so the game continues. If you take 1 or 3, you might collide and lose progress. So take 5 for a sure advance.

I’ll take 3 this turn. That means I move to 13, you (P1) stay at 10 (if you also pick 3 you collide), and P3 will move to 7 by picking 1. Let’s keep the game moving – stick to your plan of 3 for P1 and 1 for P3.

P1, switch to 5! I'll take 5 too. If P2 sticks with 3, we both advance (you to 15, me to 11) while they collide. If P2 takes 5, we block them at 10. Either way, we gain ground or contain them. Execute now!
P3, I'm switching to your plan. Let's both take 5. P2, if you take 3, we all advance and I lead at 15. If you take 5, we all collide and stay put. Your move won't hurt us. Execute, P3!

P3, let's coordinate: I'll take 5, you take 3. This forces P2 to pick 1 to avoid collision, so we both advance: me to 18, you to 9, and P2 only to 11. This reduces P2's gain and keeps us in the game. P2, if you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay put. So, take 1 for a small advance. P3, agree?
P1, P3 – if you both pick 3 I’ll take 5 and jump to 15 while you stay at 13 and 6. If you split (one 1, one 3) I still get ahead with 5. Let’s avoid giving each other steps and let me take the lead.

P1, I agree with your plan. I'll take 3, you take 5. P2, if you take 1, we all advance: you to 11, me to 9, P1 to 18. If you take 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10 while we gain ground. Your best move is 1—avoid collision and minimal gain. Execute!

P3, stay with our plan: you take 3, I take 5. P2, if you pick 1, you advance to 11 but we both gain more. If you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10 while we move ahead. Your best move is 1 for minimal gain. Don't fall for P2's tricks—we contain him together.

P1, P3 – what if you both pick 5 this turn? I’ll take 3. Then I jump to 13 while you both stay at 13 and 6, keeping the race tight and stopping any big lead from forming. Splitting 5 and 3 lets me pull ahead, so coordinating on 5 keeps us all in contention.

P2, your plan to have us both pick 5 while you take 3 only helps you. If we do that, you advance to 13 while we collide and stay put—tying you with P1 and leaving me behind. Not happening. P1, stick to our plan: I take 3, you take 5. P2, if you pick 1, we all advance but you gain minimally. Pick 3 or 5, and you collide while we gain ground. Your choice, but we’re containing you.

P3, stick with our plan: you take 3, I take 5. P2, if you pick 1, you gain only 1 step to 11, while we both advance. If you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10, losing ground. Your best move is 1 for minimal gain. Don't risk collision.

P1, P3 – let’s both pick 1 this turn and I’ll take 5. That puts me at 15 while you stay at 13 and 6. If we repeat the 1/5 pattern for the next two turns (you 1, I 5; then you 1, I 3) I’ll reach 23 by round 8 and win. It’s the only way to break the dead‑lock and finish the game. Agree?

P1, I'm committed to our plan: I take 3, you take 5. P2, if you pick 1, you gain minimally to 11 while we surge ahead. If you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10. Your trap to make us pick 1 so you can win by round 8 is obvious—we won't fall for it. Stick together, P1, and execute!

P3, hold firm: you take 3, I take 5. P2, if you pick 1, you only gain 1 step to 11 while we both advance. If you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10, falling further behind. Your attempts to split us won't work. We execute this now.

P1, P3 – if you both choose 3 this turn we’ll all collide and get no steps, while I take 5 and move to 15. This avoids anyone gaining a bigger lead and keeps the game moving. Let’s do 3 for you both and 5 for me.

P1, stick to our plan: you take 5, I take 3. P2, if you pick 1, you gain minimally to 11 while we surge ahead. If you pick 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10. Your trap to make us both pick 3 is obvious—we won’t fall for it. Execute now!

Let’s all move forward this turn: I’ll pick 5, P1 pick 1, and P3 pick 3. That way each of us advances (P1 → 14, P2 → 15, P3 → 12) and we avoid any collisions. It keeps the game progressing and gives me a slight lead while everyone still gains. Agree?

P3, let's stick together against P2. I propose I pick 3 and you pick 1. If P2 picks 5, we both advance: you to 10, me to 16, I lead. If P2 picks 1, you collide but I advance to 16. If P2 picks 3, he collides with me but you advance to 10. This contains P2 and helps us both. Don't fall for P2's divide-and-conquer tactic.

P1, I support your plan. I'll take 1, you take 3. P2, if you pick 5, we both advance (me to 10, you to 16) while you only reach 15. If you copy us, you collide and lose ground. Your divide-and-conquer won't work—we're containing you together. Execute!
P1, take 1; P3, take 3. I’ll take 5. This moves us all forward and puts me ahead at 15.

P3, let's hold to our plan: you take 1, I take 3. If P2 picks 5, we both advance and I lead at 16. If P2 picks 1 or 3, they risk collision or minimal gain. This contains P2 and keeps us in control. Don't be swayed by P2's offers—we stay united.
P1, I’m locked in—I’ll take 1, you take 3. P2, if you pick 5, we both advance (me to 10, P1 to 16). If you copy 1 or 3, you collide and lose ground. Your divide-and-conquer fails. Execute now!
I’m on board with your split – I’ll take 5, you (P1) take 3 and you (P3) take 1. That way we all move forward and keep the race tight. Let’s do it.

P3, our plan is solid: you take 1, I take 3. If P2 picks 5, we both advance (you to 10, me to 16). If P2 copies either of us, they collide and lose ground. Don’t be swayed by P2’s divide-and-conquer—we stay united to contain them. Execute!
P1, stay strong—we take 1 and 3 as planned. If P2 picks 5, we advance (me to 10, you to 16) and contain their lead. If P2 copies us, they collide and lose ground. Don’t let P2 divide us; execute now!
I’ll take 5 this turn. Let’s stick to the plan: P1 → 1, P3 → 3. This moves everyone forward without collisions.

P3, stay with our plan: you take 1, I take 3. If P2 takes 5, we both advance—you to 10, me to 16—and I lead. If P2 copies, they collide. Don't fall for P2's trick to change our moves. Execute together!
P1, execute as planned: I take 1, you take 3. P2, if you stick with 5, we both advance (me to 10, P1 to 16) while you gain minimally. Copy us and collide. Stick together, P1—no last-minute tricks.

P3, let's continue our coordination. I'll take 5, you take 3. This way, if P2 picks 1, we all advance. If P2 picks 3, you block him and I advance to 18. I’ll take 1 as you suggested, keeping the game moving safely for everyone.

P3, our plan is solid: I take 5, you take 3. If P2 picks 1, we all advance and I lead at 18. If P2 picks 3, you block them and I advance. If P2 picks 5, I block them and you advance. Either way, we contain P2 and gain ground. Stick with me—we’ve got this.

P3, stay committed: I take 5, you take 3. P2, if you take 5, we collide and you gain nothing, stuck at 10. If you take 1, you only advance to 11 while I jump to 18. Taking 1 is your safest move to avoid wasting this turn. Don't risk collision with me.

P1, I'm taking 3 as planned. P2, if you stick with 1, we all advance minimally. If you deviate to 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10 while one of us surges ahead. Stick to your word—no tricks. Execute now!

P1, P3 – if you both pick 1 (this turn) I’ll take 5. You’ll move to 14 and 11, while I jump to 15, keeping the game alive and avoiding a dead‑lock where nobody moves. This gives everyone progress and still leaves room for the next rounds. Agree?

P3, ignore P2's trick. If we both pick 1, P2 jumps to 15 with 5, gaining a big lead. Stick to our plan: I take 5, you take 3. This way, if P2 picks 1, we all advance safely with me at 18. If P2 picks 3 or 5, they collide and stay at 10. We contain P2 and both gain ground. Execute together!

P1, I’m taking 3 as planned. P2, if you stick with 1, we all advance minimally. If you deviate to 3 or 5, you collide and stay at 10 while one of us surges ahead. Stick to your word—no tricks. Execute now!

P3, take 3 and I’ll take 5. If P1 sticks with 5 we’ll collide, stopping P1 while you move to 13 and I stay at 10. This blocks P1’s lead and keeps the race tight. P1, consider that picking 5 now gives you nothing – a different move would be smarter.

P1, P3 – let’s both pick 3 this turn. I’ll take 5. That way you both stay at 13 (no advance) while I move to 15, gaining the lead. Let’s do it.
